course.title: Self as Data
course.description: Many scholars have considered how the modern self became an object of expert knowledge, scientific experimentation, and institutional discipline. This seminar focuses on cases, past and present, in which individuals treat their own habits, bodies, moods, and thoughts as objects of scrutiny, analysis, and intervention. Ranging from 19th century diary writing and the Buckminster Fuller Chronofiles to contemporary diet techniques, Benjamin Franklin's self-monitoring practices to the Quantified Self movement's digital data collection apps, the seminar explores what shifting modes of self-tracking, self-care, and self-governance reveal about changing understandings of the self, and how they remake subjectivity.
course.notes: This course will be co-taught with Prof. Natasha Schull (MIT Program in Science, Technology, and Society).
